abstract.p: Eutectic melt of multiple electrolytes enables record performance for solvent-free dye-sensitized solar cells.

custom-meta.meta-value: Surface and Interface Science, Thin Films

notes.p: This research highlight has been approved by the author of the original article and all empirical data contained within has been provided by said author.

body.p: Researchers from the Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry in China and the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology1 have demonstrated a solvent-free dye-sensitized solar cell that converts sunlight to electricity with unprecedented efficiency. This performance was achieved by the use of an innovative solvent-free electrolyte that consisted of a mixture of multiple iodide salts. This development brings flexible, light-weight, low-cost solar cells a step closer to commercial reality.

In conventional photovoltaic solar cells, the generation of electrons and holes by the absorption of light and their separation and transport takes place within a single semiconducting material, most commonly silicon. But in a dye-sensitized solar cell the generation and transport of charge is realized by two different materials. In such a cell, charge is first generated when light is absorbed by semiconducting nanoparticles doped with photosensitive dye molecules attached to their surface. This charge is then transported through an electrolyte in which the nanoparticles are held.

Although the performance of dye-sensitized solar cells is currently not as high as silicon-based photovoltaics, they are cheaper, lighter and can be built from flexible and less fragile materials. This makes them preferable for applications where portability and mechanical robustness are more important (Fig. 1).
Fig. 1: Dye-sensitized solar cells have the potential to be flexible and more mechanically robust than conventional photovoltaic solar cells. This makes the attractive for portable energy generation applications, such as this solar power.

High efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells incorporate electrolytes that require volatile organic solvents. This means that they must be encapsulated within structures that prevent these solvents from leaking out, which limits their use in harsh outdoor environments.

To address this problem, Peng Wang, Michael Grätzel (one of the inventors of the dye-sensitized solar cell) and colleagues investigated certain iodide salts as solvent-free electrolytes. Unexpectedly, they found that although two salts, EMII and DMII, were worse conductors at room temperature than the promising previously investigated candidate, PMII, at temperatures above their melting point, both performed better. This prompted them to combine these and other salts together to create a series of so-called eutectic melts — composite mixtures whose melting point is lower and electrolytic performance is higher than any of their individual components.
The best of these electrolytes enabled the researchers to achieve light conversion efficiencies of up to 8.2% — about 1% higher than any previous solvent-free cell.
